ratings.question_text: What is your overall assessment of this course?

narratives.question_text: How would you summarize AFAM 505 01/AMST 643 01 for a fellow student? Would you recommend AFAM 505 01/AMST 643 01 to another student? Why or why not?
comments: Interesting course, challenging but fair if you come to lecture and spend time reviewing the material. I would recommend it.
Some self studying is required. Yes, because it is a great opportunity to learn about spectroscopy in detail.

I would definitely recommend this course to every graduate students as long as the research is related. This also applies to the other two related courses (MoRad I, and experimentation in chemistry - also by Prof.Johnson).

This class provides an introductory examination of traditional spectroscopy from a quantum mechanical background. If you can keep up with the, at times, unorganized small, highly interactive lectures, you will learn a lot from this class. The homework is useful and the computational assignments were very satisfying when perfected. Would recommend to others.

narratives.question_text: How did this course deepen your knowledge of your discipline/profession? To what extent did this course contribute to your dissertation/research?
comments: I think this course will help me in my research.

This course emphasizes the importance of understanding spectroscopy, photochemistry, and chemical reaction dynamics by relating the contents learned in class to actual research papers. I learned a lot. This course contributes a large extent to my dissertation/research.
Although I am not going to look into the details of spectroscopy for my research, these background/advanced knowledge are especially important to avoid pitfalls when using any related tools.
